@SBF_Alameda @AliceCrypt @namshik Fully agree. We have decided to take an alternate path of using the data that is on hand (web traffic, liquidity, time and sales) to predict volumes via a trained model and track reported vs predicted, and flag out errant exchanges instead. Will be launching this soon! üòÄ

@SBF_Alameda @AliceCrypt @namshik (3/3) Account-ID information and graph modeling the relationship between accounts and trades to fully appreciate if there is any malpractice here. We simply do not have that information to make very precise determination of wash trading, and can only guess/estimate.

@SBF_Alameda @AliceCrypt @namshik (2/3) If we went down this path, we would need to continuously adjust the "time" variable and make the model unusable because we would just get too many false positives. In essence, the detection of wash trading needs to be done via

@SBF_Alameda @AliceCrypt @namshik (1/3) We think this form of testing is heavily dependent on the threshold of time defined for "BBO". More sophisticated wash trading techniques focus on RNGing this element (shouldn't be too difficult to do), waiting for 1 sec or so, before trading themselves out.
@SBF_Alameda (2/2) and we used this data to inform our "slippage simulator", which tests the slippage of multiple order sizes and weighed them based on the distribution above.
@SBF_Alameda (1/2) We definitely did a volume weight of time & sales and performed a distribution analysis of them. As suspected, the distribution followed a power-law,
@IAMKINGGABRIEL This is an improved liquidity score for the exchanges: https://t.co/nxMuaVpYyf Liquidity for assets and market pairs coming in June! üôÇ

@AliceCrypt @namshik @SBF_Alameda As mentioned, we can only report what exchange report on their public API, and evaluate the data based on that. The only real way to test would be to send actual orders into the book and evaluate. We would appreciate any feedback based on that testing. üôÇ
@SBF_Alameda We stopped including stablecoin/stablecoin pairs in exchange average liquidity. We still do provide that data for SC/SC pairs.

@SBF_Alameda Based on checking trade size distribution of BTC USD pairs across various exchanges, the 75% quartile is still relatively small. We used this distribution to inform the different order sizes we simulate to produce our score.

@SBF_Alameda Right now, we are taking the top 25 market averages. We are still refining this as liquidity across different assets are spread out across a power-law distribution, yet we want to emphasis the importance of providing liquidity for the alt coins.

@SBF_Alameda We can only report what exchanges report to us via their public API. Liquidity is always tricky to report (spread vs depth). We had to choose what we thought mattered most to users (slippage) and focused on that.
@SBF_Alameda Thank you!! üòÄ

@pjtuttle All in all, a vibrant derivatives market will help to drive adoption of crypto to the masses as service providers can better manage their price and liquidity risks.
@pjtuttle In addition, derivatives also allow stakeholders in the space (miners, exchanges, OTC desks, crypto-users etc.) to hedge price and time risk of the underlying asset.
@pjtuttle Financial derivatives create liquidity in the underlying asset that they are "derived" from. This allows all users to buy and sell the asset with greater ease and with lesser slippage.

@AdeldMeyer (1/5) The launch of CoinMarketCap indices (administered by Solactive, which is fully compliant with IOSCO Principles for Financial Benchmarks) necessitates periodic audits of the Top 200. Ranking is determined by market cap and factors highlighted in the methodology.
